author: By Dani Blum
title: 5 Big Myths About Money and Parenting
description: Common financial advice, demystified and unpacked.
content: This piece is part of “The Price of Modern Parenting.” Read more about the gig economy, the cost of adoption and out-of-pocket expenses for preterm births.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Cambodia’s Coronavirus Complacency May Exact a Global Toll
description: After a cruise ship docked in Cambodia, passengers streamed off the ship, maskless, and fears are rising that the country could become a vector of transmission.
content: SIHANOUKVILLE, Cambodia — When Cambodia’s prime minister greeted passengers on a cruise ship amid a coronavirus scare on Valentine’s Day, embraces were the order of the day. Protective masks were not.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Cambodia’s Coronavirus Complacency May Have Global Consequences
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 18, 2020.
content: “This is influenza-like transmission. It’s like trying to stop the wind.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Bolton Hints at Further Revelations if He Overcomes White House ‘Censorship’
description: In his first public appearance since the impeachment trial, the president’s former national security adviser said he was fighting efforts to suppress his unpublished book.
content: DURHAM, N.C. — John R. Bolton, the former national security adviser to President Trump, suggested on Monday that his unpublished book contained far more revelations than just the campaign to pressure Ukraine for help with domestic politics but said he was fighting “censorship” by the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Man in the Red Coat,’ by Julian Barnes: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “The Man in the Red Coat,” by Julian Barnes
content: In June 1885, three Frenchmen arrived in London. One was a Prince, one was a Count, and the third was a commoner with an Italian surname. The Count subsequently described their purpose as “intellectual and decorative shopping.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: On Politics: Bloomberg’s in the Debate
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Continent Remade’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the Year of Africa in 1960, when 17 African countries declared their independence.
content: Featured Article: “A Continent Remade”

title: Michael Bloomberg’s Not-So-Secret Weapon
description: The media tycoon and former New York mayor has paid his way into a position of influence in the Democratic Party. But can he buy a presidential nomination?

title: ‘Real Life,’ by Brandon Taylor: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Real Life,” by Brandon Taylor
content: It was a cool evening in late summer when Wallace, his father dead for several weeks, decided that he would meet his friends at the pier after all. The lake was dimpled with white waves. People coveted these last blustery days of summer before the weather turned cold and mercurial. The air was heavy with their good times as the white people scattered across the tiered patios, pried their mouths apart, and beamed their laughter into each other’s faces. Overhead, gulls drifted easy as anything.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Were Never Going to Venmo the Same $15 Again’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Newly paraplegic at the age of 23, I needed answers. Where to live, how to live, why to live? One afternoon a colleague (and secret crush) visited me at the rehabilitation center. He took me on my first, terrifying foray into the real world down 34th Street in Manhattan. I told him I wanted to return when I couldn’t bear the stares of passers-by any longer. He said, “They are staring at you because they’ve never seen a woman so beautiful.” Tongue-tied, I looked up at him and saw love looking back. It was the only answer I needed. — Lauren Furst
source.name: The New York Times

title: Selenis Leyva, Living High in Lincoln Square
description: The “Orange Is the New Black” actor has a new series and her own space high above it all, where (almost) everything is white — just the way she wanted it.
content: The “Orange Is the New Black” actor has a new series and her own space high above it all, where (almost) everything is white — just the way she wanted it.

title: Reality Winner, Imprisoned for Leaking Russian Hacking Report, Seeks Clemency
description: The Air Force veteran is serving more than five years in prison for sending a classified report to a news website while she was working as a National Security Agency contractor.
content: An Air Force veteran who has been imprisoned for nearly three years for leaking a classified report on Russian hacking while she was an intelligence contractor applied for clemency from President Trump on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Exclusive Details on Michael Bloomberg’s Plan to Rein In Wall Street
description: The presidential candidate’s proposals for changing how the financial industry is regulated wouldn’t be out of place for his more left-leaning rivals.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Widdicombe
title: Thom Browne Got Techie for Fashion Week
description: And the Bowery Mission gala had some French glamour.
content: With giants like Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein absent from New York Fashion Week, it was up to tech brands like Samsung to bring what little buzz there was to this season’s runway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Save Scouting. End the Boy Scouts.
description: Scouting as an idea is valuable, even vital. And we don’t need a toxic organization to do it.
content: Thirty years ago this summer, I spent two weeks backpacking across Philmont, a 140,000-acre expanse of northeastern New Mexico owned by the Boy Scouts of America. Most people who trek Philmont say it changed their life; it certainly changed mine. A few years later, I became an Eagle Scout — still one of my proudest achievements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monica Davey and Mitch Smith
title: Who Is Rod Blagojevich? Why Did President Trump Commute His Sentence?
description: Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat and  former governor of Illinois, was accused of trying to sell the Senate seat left open when Barack Obama went to the White House.
content: CHICAGO — Rod R. Blagojevich, whose criminal sentence President Trump has commuted, became a household name when he was arrested 12 years ago on an explosive accusation: Prosecutors said he had tried to sell or trade to the highest bidder the Senate seat that Barack Obama was vacating to become the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: The iPhone at the Deathbed
description: Families are photographing death at home. These photos may feel jarring on Facebook, but the practice itself has a long history.
content: After Robert Alexander died at 51 during heart surgery in June 2018, after he was taken from the hospital to the facility that would recover the tissue and bone he had donated, he was brought to his uncle’s farm in Hinton, Okla., where his six siblings, his mother and other family members and friends had gathered to give him a home funeral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Need a New Driver’s License to Fly? Prepare for a Real Wait.
description: D.M.V. lines are longer than ever as states struggle to issue the new licenses, which will be required for domestic flights starting Oct. 1.
content: Motor vehicle offices are a particular sort of urban hell where people spend hour after hour waiting — waiting to take a number, waiting to have a photograph snapped, waiting to take a vision test, waiting to be called to a clerk’s window.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: On Tour, Pompeo Courts Africa, to Counter China
description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, on his first visit to sub-Saharan Africa, promotes partnerships with American companies, but finds China’s presence pervasive.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — When U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo landed in Ethiopia as part of his first foray into sub-Saharan Africa, he arrived in a city shaped by the same adversary that he had come to preach against: China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Trumpian Liberalism of Michael Bloomberg
description: He may be running as the anti-Trump, but when it comes to the politics of racial control, there is a resemblance.
content: Donald Trump is who he is as a politician because of his unapologetically racial vision of the American nation. Trump’s America is white, and he sees his job as protecting that whiteness from black and brown people who might come to the country or claim greater status within it. That’s what it meant to “make America great again.” And he’s delivered, using the power of the office and the force of the state to attack and stigmatize black and brown people, from outspoken celebrities to ordinary immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: A Hometown Exhibition Will Showcase August Wilson’s Process
description: The show will open in the late fall at the August Wilson African American Cultural Center in downtown Pittsburgh.
content: Great playwrights are often eclipsed by their work and the actors who give voice to it, but a coming exhibition dedicated to August Wilson will focus on the man behind the words. The August Wilson African American Cultural Center in Pittsburgh announced on Tuesday that this fall it would open “August Wilson: A Writer’s Landscape,” a permanent show about the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright’s life, creative process and legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Trump Contradicts Advisers on China Technology Fears
description: The president, in a series of tweets, said the U.S. would not restrict sales to the country, a sharp shift in administration policy.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump publicly objected to efforts within his own administration to restrict the sales of American technology to China over national security concerns, insisting on Tuesday that such fears were an “excuse” and that the United States was open for business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaclyn Peiser
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $49/SQ. FT.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Cooper
title: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center to Explore Schubert
description: A festival on “The Magic of Schubert” will anchor its 2020-21 season.
content: Concert halls around the world are programming Beethoven this year to celebrate the 250th anniversary of his birth. So it is perhaps fitting that the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center decided to focus next season on one of Beethoven’s greatest admirers: Schubert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Sanford
title: Why Do My Fellow Republicans Make Excuses for Trump’s Deficits?
description: He is driving the country to financial ruin. And his own party is letting it happen.
content: People have a tragic flaw: Sometimes we want others to do the thinking for us. And across the ages promoters and con men have been more than willing to oblige. They invite us to indulge in the fantasy that a newfound father figure will fix it all, though it never works out that way.

title: Boy Scouts Seek Bankruptcy to Survive a Deluge of Sex-Abuse Claims
description: The nonprofit group, which counts more than two million youth participants, follows Catholic dioceses and U.S.A. Gymnastics in seeking bankruptcy protection amid sex-abuse cases.
content: Hoping to contain a deluge of sexual-abuse lawsuits, the Boy Scouts of America took shelter in bankruptcy court on Tuesday, filing for Chapter 11 protection that will let the group keep operating while it grapples with questions about the future of the century-old Scouting movement.

content: The trouble with Picasso, Julian Barnes wrote, reprovingly, in his essay collection, “Keeping an Eye Open,” is that he didn’t make paintings — he made Picassos.

description: Echoing fellow stars like Cody Bellinger and Mike Trout, the Yankees’ cornerstone player didn’t hold back on the Astros’ cheating-stained title: “You didn’t earn it.”
content: TAMPA, Fla. — For just a moment on Tuesday, at the start of his news conference after the Yankees’ first full workout of spring training, Aaron Judge seemed torn.

author: By Thomas Kaplan, Kate Conger and Reid J. Epstein
title: Bloomberg Campaign Opens First Attack on a Democratic Rival: Bernie Sanders
description: Michael R. Bloomberg’s campaign mounted a direct offensive against a Democratic opponent for the first time, as Bernie Sanders shot back by accusing the billionaire of trying to buy the presidency.
content: RENO, Nev. — Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s presidential campaign, which has largely focused its attacks on President Trump, on Monday mounted a frontal offensive against one of his Democratic rivals for the first time, comparing Senator Bernie Sanders’s campaign tactics with those employed by the president.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Adventurer’s Son,’ by Roman Dial: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from ‘The Adventurer’s Son,’ by Roman Dial
content: My wife, Peggy, bore our son, Cody Roman Dial, on February 22, 1987, in Fairbanks, Alaska. Peggy and I had met as teenagers there, a place that drew me for its prospect of climbing mountains, skiing glaciers, and rafting rivers. We purposefully raised Cody Roman and his sister, Jazz, in Alaska, exposing them both to natural history travel and wilderness experiences around the world. When he was six, Cody Roman and I hiked alone across sixty miles of an empty Aleutian island. When he was nine, we made a family trip to a remote national park in Indonesian Borneo, a life-changing experience in an amazing tropical rainforest. While activities like wilderness trips and travel in the developing world set him apart from many kids, Cody Roman played with Legos and video games, listened to indie rock, read Harry Potter, and attended public school as a normal kid from a close-knit family brought closer by nature and adventure. As a professional scientist and explorer, I included him in science and explorations as my favored and willing partner in both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: Behind the Wheel, Behind the Eight Ball
description: Jackie Heinricher built an all-star team of female racecar drivers. Then the money ran out.

description: Germany seems poised to follow Britain in letting the Chinese maker build next-generation networks, despite last appeals from the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — America’s global campaign to prevent its closest allies from using Huawei, the Chinese telecom giant, in the next generation of wireless networks has largely failed, with foreign leaders publicly rebuffing the United States argument that the firm poses an unmanageable security threat.

title: 6-Year-Old Held in Mental Health Center for 2 Days Without Mother’s Consent
description: Under a Florida law called the Baker Act, Nadia King was removed from her Jacksonville elementary school this month after she reportedly had a series of outbursts.
content: A Florida kindergartner was sent to a mental health center against her mother’s wishes and held there for 48 hours this month after she reportedly threw tantrums at her school.

author: By Christopher Bollen
title: Who Was Carlo Scarpa?
description: His reimagining of ancient public buildings made him an Italian icon, but the 20th-century architect is perhaps best understood through the private homes he designed.
content: WHEN MARIA CAGNOLI, a 63-year-old rheumatologist from the Northern Italian town of Bergamo, stepped off the elevator onto the top floor of a converted 17th-century Venice palazzo for a satellite exhibition a week before the 2015 Biennale, she had no idea she was about to become a caretaker of history.
source.name: The New York Times

description: A prominent figure on the Greenwich Village folk scene of the 1960s, he wrote songs performed by Bette Midler, Carly Simon and the Muppets.

content: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)

content: SILIVRI, Turkey — A Turkish court on Tuesday acquitted nine people accused of trying to overthrow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, in a surprising verdict interpreted as an important concession by the government in a trial widely criticized as unjust both at home and abroad.

title: Sugars With a Floral Note
description: Il Fiorista now sells dusting sugars flavored with jasmine, cloves or orange blossoms.
content: Il Fiorista, the Mediterranean restaurant with a floral theme and a retail counter, is now selling condiments seasoned with flowers, spices and herbs. Among them are intriguingly scented sugars: coarse-textured orange blossom-vanilla, finer jasmine-honey and powdery clove maple. Your French toast will never be the same. They also sell butterfly pea flowers, a trendy cocktail ingredient to add color to your drink. The glass packaging makes it worthy of a gift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Dinners Laud Chefs at Beatrice Inn
description: Angie Mar, the chef and an owner of the West Village restaurant, has special events planned honoring some of her culinary heroes.
content: Angie Mar, an owner and chef of the Beatrice Inn in the West Village, has long looked up to culinary giants like André Soltner, Jacques Pépin, Jacques Torres, Alain Sailhac and Julia Child. Now, to honor them, she has organized a series of dinners where some of their signature dishes will be served, and each of the chefs except Child, who died in 2004, will be on hand. “They laid the groundwork,” Ms. Mar said. “They influenced a whole generation, including me.” The first dinner, March 31, will feature the food of Mr. Sailhac and Mr. Torres and commemorate Le Cirque and the champvallon, a meat and potato dish for which the restaurant was known. On April 28, Mr. Pépin will be honored with chicken with Cognac and cream. May 20 will feature a menu from Mr. Soltner, with sea urchins in Champagne jelly. And for Child, on June 16, Ms. Mar will serve beef bourguignon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Bean for Your Irish Coffee
description: A coffee infused with Egan’s Irish Whiskey from Fire Dept. Coffee is the perfect match for that St. Patrick’s Day cocktail.
content: Among the beans sold by Fire Dept. Coffee in Rockford, Ill., a company founded by firefighters, are some infused with spirits, including bourbon, rum, tequila and Irish whiskey. The whiskey flavor is worth having on hand to make Irish coffee, the winter warmer soon to be in great demand. Though the whole beans smell of coffee, the whiskey aroma comes through once ground, even subtly perfuming the coffee in the cup with a volatile hint of malty spirit. They use Egan’s Vintage Grain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Stanford
title: Coronavirus, Michael Bloomberg, Boy Scouts: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here's what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: How Elizabeth Warren’s Camp Is Seeking to Regain the Spotlight
description: Ms. Warren’s campaign and her allies, convinced her message is being ignored, see a path forward — and they say writing her off would be a mistake.
content: RENO, Nev. — A bad month for Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts keeps getting worse. She finished in a respectable third place in the Iowa caucuses, but a results-tallying meltdown muddled what could have been a good evening. New Hampshire was better at logistics but worse for her candidacy, considering she ended up closer to candidates who dropped out after the primary than those who finished on top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Maggie Astor
title: Michael Bloomberg Surges in Polls and Qualifies for 2 Democratic Debates
description: After garnering 19 percent support in a national poll, the billionaire will be on the debate stage, where he is certain to be a target of onstage criticism.
content: WASHINGTON — Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York has qualified for the next two Democratic debates, including one on Wednesday in Las Vegas. It will be his first appearance onstage alongside his presidential rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: basal
description: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Nocera
title: What’s Driving the Millennial Political Takeover?
description: Mayors’ offices, city councils and Congress are flooded with young people. In “The Ones We’ve Been Waiting For,” Charlotte Alter explains why.
content: THE ONES WE’VE BEEN WAITING FOR How a New Generation of Leaders Will Transform AmericaBy Charlotte Alter
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Damour
title: Why Teenagers Reject Parents’ Solutions to Their Problems
description: It’s usually because we’re not giving them what they’re really looking for.
content: Parents of adolescents are often confronted by a puzzling sequence of events. First, teenagers bring us their problems; second, we earnestly offer suggestions and solutions; and third, teenagers dismiss our ideas as irritating, irrelevant or both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: An Afghan Killed 2 Americans. The U.S. Government Issued the Gun.
description: The Department of Defense has dispatched hundreds of thousands of small arms to Afghan security forces. It was one of these weapons that left two U.S. troops dead in a recent insider attack.
content: On Feb. 8 an Afghan soldier turned his American-supplied M249 light machine gun on a group of American and Afghan commandos who were huddled and patiently waiting for an airlift from a small base in eastern Afghanistan’s Nangarhar Province.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Ivan Penn
title: What’s Happening With Plans to Restructure PG&E?
description: Tuesday: An update on efforts to wrest the state’s largest utility from investors’ hands. Also: Kobe Bryant and the Lakers.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Johnson and Malina Joseph Gilchrist
title: Spring’s Most Shapely Silhouettes
description: A black-and-white color palette allows dramatic forms — and the dramatic landscape of the English countryside — to flourish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blair Braverman
title: His Son Hiked Into the Costa Rican Jungle, and Never Came Out. What Happened?
description: After Cody Dial disappeared, his father — the ecologist and explorer Roman Dial — set out to find him, a tale he recounts in “The Adventurer’s Son.”
content: THE ADVENTURER’S SONA MemoirBy Roman Dial
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isadora Zubillaga
title: A Free and Fair Presidential Election Is Venezuela’s Way Forward
description: Efforts to end the country’s crisis at the ballot box must synchronize national, regional and international approaches.
content: PARIS — People in Venezuela are starving, suffering and have been fleeing the country at a rate of 5,000 per day. The crisis has reverberated far beyond our borders. It’s becoming increasingly clear that the stability of the hemisphere depends on what both Venezuelans and our global partners are willing to do in order to move forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: Earrings That Flicker With Balletic Grace
description: From Van Cleef & Arpels, jewel-and-pearl pieces that all but dance on the ear.
content: When the choreographer George Balanchine debuted “Jewels” in 1967 at the New York City Ballet’s new home at Lincoln Center, it was considered the first full-evening abstract ballet. Cynics speculated that, with sparkly costumes and three acts titled “Emeralds,” “Rubies” and “Diamonds,” he was trying to attract a glitzier crowd for the relatively proletarian dance company. But he insisted his inspiration came from the gems in the Fifth Avenue windows of Van Cleef & Arpels, the Parisian jeweler run by Claude Arpels. Claude’s uncle, Louis, had been the first Arpels to recognize the elegant symbiosis between gems and the ballet, commissioning the now 124-year-old maison’s signature ballerina clips in the 1940s. Van Cleef & Arpels has continued to reference dance throughout its history, most recently with these earrings made in the dangling rounded-pendant balletti style, inspired by the jewel-toned ball gowns worn by women during the Italian Renaissance. While both pairs feature diamonds and pearls, one suggests spring, with a confection of rubies and pink sapphires, and the other gestures toward fall, with emeralds, yellow sapphires and black spinels. Both dance and spin weightlessly in the light, alive with effervescent grace. Price on request, vancleefarpels.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheelah Kolhatkar
title: Her Blog Post About Uber Upended Big Tech. Now She’s Written a Memoir.
description: In “Whistleblower,” Susan Fowler, a former software engineer at Uber, describes the harassment she endured while working at the company.
content: WHISTLEBLOWERMy Journey to Silicon Valley and  Fight for Justice at UberBy Susan Fowler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Pessimistic Outlook in Russia Slows Investment, and the Economy
description: Growth has slowed to well below the global average as economists point to low spending by the government and the private sector.
content: MOSCOW — Last year, Russia set a goal to quicken its economic expansion — to grow faster than the world as a whole — as a way to secure the country’s position as a dominant global power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Trump Continues Attack on Federal Case Against Friend
description: President Trump threatened to sue “everyone all over the place” involved in the special counsel inquiry and continued public attacks on the case against his associate Roger J. Stone Jr.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump threatened on Tuesday to sue “everyone” involved in the now-closed special counsel inquiry and continued his attacks on the federal case against his longtime friend and adviser Roger J. Stone Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Thom Browne Releases a Flip Phone
description: And Bowery Mission holds a Valentine’s Gala.
content: And Bowery Mission holds a Valentine’s Gala.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: How to Build Healthy Habits
description: It’s not about willpower. Good habits happen when we set ourselves up for success. Our new challenge will show you how.
content: We’re all creatures of habit. We tend to wake up at the same time each day, brush our teeth, have morning coffee and commute to work, following the same patterns every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Miller
title: Will the U.S.-Taliban Deal End the War?
description: The value of the expected agreement between the United States and the Taliban lies in opening the door to an Afghan peace process.
content: The talks between the United States and the Taliban in Doha, Qatar, which were abruptly canceled by President Trump in September, are back on track. After several months of diplomatic regrouping, American and Taliban negotiators are once again on the verge of sealing a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sammar Atassi
title: My Father in Syria Needed Pills
description: It took two weeks for them to get to him. By then it was too late.
content: My father had dementia. He also had Parkinson’s disease. He died at age 85, a week after the Parkinson’s pills arrived, their having taken more than 5,000 miles and two weeks to get to Syria. I am not sure that the lack of medicine is what caused his death, but it might as well have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: How a Pharmacy Handles Mask Hoarders and Coronavirus Fears
description: At a small pharmacy in Hong Kong, part of the job has become calming nervous customers desperate for supplies.
content: HONG KONG — “It’s like World War III,” said May Tang, an employee at the Kit Pharm Dispensary Ltd. in Hong Kong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Michael J. de la Merced, Emily Flitter and Stacy Cowley
title: Michael Bloomberg Leans Left With Plan to Rein In Wall St.
description: Some of the billionaire’s proposals wouldn’t be out of place for his more progressive presidential rivals.
content: Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday offered his proposals for regulating Wall Street, where he made his billions, promising a return of Obama-era oversight if elected president and invoking the name of one of his rivals, Senator Elizabeth Warren, in an attempt to connect with the Democratic Party’s progressive wing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Cruise Giant Carnival Works to Manage Deepening Coronavirus Crisis
description: Carnival could be hurt financially after passengers on two of its ships were found to be infected.
content: The arrival of the Westerdam cruise ship in Cambodia seemed like cause for celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Katie Benner and Sharon LaFraniere
title: As Trump Claims to Be Law of the Land, Barr’s Irritation Builds
description: The president broadly asserted his authority of the criminal justice system, attacking law enforcement officials and issuing pardons.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump and Attorney General William P. Barr agree on one thing at least: The president is making the attorney general’s job much harder. What they don’t agree on: Mr. Trump sees no reason to stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Noam Scheiber
title: Kickstarter Employees Vote to Unionize in a Big Step for Tech
description: Engineers and others at the crowdfunding platform voted narrowly to form a union, one of the first tech companies to do so.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Employees at the crowdfunding platform Kickstarter voted on Tuesday to unionize, the first well-known technology company to take the step toward being represented by organized labor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blair Braverman
title: His Son Hiked Into the Costa Rican Jungle, and Never Came Out. What Happened?
description: After Cody Dial disappeared, his father — the ecologist and explorer Roman Dial — set out to find him, a tale he recounts in “The Adventurer’s Son.”
content: THE ADVENTURER’S SONA MemoirBy Roman Dial
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Pessimistic Outlook in Russia Slows Investment, and the Economy
description: Growth has slowed to well below the global average as economists point to low spending by the government and the private sector.
content: MOSCOW — Last year, Russia set a goal to quicken its economic expansion — to grow faster than the world as a whole — as a way to secure the country’s position as a dominant global power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Zoe Caldwell, Winner of Four Tony Awards, Is Dead at 86
description: Her signature performances included the title role in “The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie” and Maria Callas in “Master Class.”
content: Zoe Caldwell, who won Tony Awards — four in all — in the 1960s, ’80s and ’90s, the last for portraying the opera star Maria Callas in “Master Class,” Terrence McNally’s study of the twilight of the singer’s career, died on Sunday at her home in Pound Ridge, N.Y., in Westchester County. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: To Make a Diplomatic Point, Ukraine Rebels Open Fire
description: A separatist assault was seen as aimed at weakening Ukraine’s president and gaining leverage in talks to end the war in the country’s east.
content: Russian-backed separatists tried on Tuesday to break through the trench line in the stalemated war in eastern Ukraine, killing one government soldier and wounding four others, the Ukrainian military said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Russian Oil Company Supporting Venezuela’s Leader
description: The penalties seek to pressure President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela to give up power, nearly two years after he was re-elected in a widely disputed vote.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States on Tuesday imposed tough economic sanctions against a Russian oil giant that is keeping Venezuela’s ruling government afloat, gambling that the newest penalties against President Nicolás Maduro will not roil global oil prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: First Ebola, Now Coronavirus. Why an Omaha Hospital Gets the Toughest Cases.
description: A biocontainment unit that drew attention for treating Ebola patients in 2014 is now evaluating more than a dozen cruise ship evacuees for the coronavirus.
content: In the years after the Sept. 11 attacks, officials at Nebraska Medical Center envisioned a time when the nation would need a large, secure treatment center to guard against the threats of bioterrorism and infectious diseases. They spent $1 million to transform an empty wing of the hospital into a 10-bed biocontainment unit, complete with concrete walls, filtered air and video links to the nursing station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: Utah Powder and Steeps, Without the Crowds
description: Head north from Salt Lake City to visit Snowbasin and Powder Mountain, relatively undiscovered gems of the state’s ski scene.
content: During a quick swing through Utah last spring, I texted my husband a photo from a ski area of rock- and tree-lined steeps. “Is that Snowbird or Alta?” he responded. His guess was good, but he was about 70 miles off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Michael J. de la Merced
title: HSBC Plans to Cut 35,000 Jobs, Weighed Down by Virus and Hong Kong Unrest
description: The London-based bank aims to cut $4.5 billion in costs and scale back its Western operations.
content: HONG KONG — HSBC plans to cut 35,000 jobs over the next three years as the global bank scales back its Western operations to focus on faster-growing Asian markets, particularly China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: In England, Closing a Chapter of Modern Dance
description: Richard Alston’s company is packing it in. (Yes, the culprit is money.) Before the last performances in March, the company will perform in New Jersey.
content: Imagine if one of America’s most respected modern-dance companies realized that its funding model was no longer sustainable and had to cease operations. This despite having name recognition and a highly identifiable style, and still regularly producing new work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: There’s a Story Around This Cake
description: A new loaf cake from Breads Bakery is wrapped in a short story from the Israeli writer Etgar Keret.
content: For its new Keret Cake, Breads Bakery’s Proustian moment was a short story, “Crumb Cake,” by Etgar Keret, an award-winning Israeli author who wrote it for the bakery. The cake, a moist, slightly citrusy golden loaf topped with crumbs and bits of dried raspberry, was created by a Breads baker, with input from the writer. Each cake, on sale starting Thursday, comes wrapped in a copy of the story, which is about a teenager, not a cake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Judge Weighs How to Keep Guantánamo’s 9/11 Trial on Track
description: At issue is a defense lawyer’s request to leave the case for health reasons. In court, the prosecutor opposed the move, saying there is no “medical emergency.”
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Affirmative Action Opponents Renew Their Battle Against Harvard
description: A group representing Asian-American students is appealing a judge’s ruling that Harvard did not explicitly discriminate against them by boosting other racial and ethnic groups.
content: A group that opposes affirmative action filed an appeal Tuesday of a federal ruling that Harvard had not intentionally discriminated against Asian-American applicants, ratcheting up a challenge to decades of Supreme Court decisions upholding race-conscious selection in college admissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Bethany Mollenkof
title: An Immigrant From Brazil Has Changed Lives as a Coach. Is That Enough to Stay in the U.S.?
description: Hicu Motta turned a group of working-class girls into first-class rowers. But immigration authorities rejected his bid for a green card.
content: LOS ANGELES — For the past three years, Henrique “Hicu” Motta, a rowing coach, has created unlikely success stories in a sport long associated with the privileged. He has taken his team of high school girls from working-class families to the national championships and sent several of them to Division I colleges on athletic scholarships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: The Anything but Humble Carrot
description: Yotam Ottolenghi thinks this root vegetable has a fascinating history and is best enjoyed intact, its color and shape on display.
content: LONDON — “You ask me what life is,” wrote the great Russian playwright Anton Chekhov. “That’s like asking what a carrot is. A carrot is a carrot, and there’s nothing more to know.” Well, Anton, I think there’s a lot more that can be said and known about the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: There’s a Story Around This Cake
description: A new loaf cake from Breads Bakery is wrapped in a short story from the Israeli writer Etgar Keret.
content: For its new Keret Cake, Breads Bakery’s Proustian moment was a short story, “Crumb Cake,” by Etgar Keret, an award-winning Israeli author who wrote it for the bakery. The cake, a moist, slightly citrusy golden loaf topped with crumbs and bits of dried raspberry, was created by a Breads baker, with input from the writer. Each cake, on sale starting Thursday, comes wrapped in a copy of the story, which is about a teenager, not a cake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: At the Intersection of Cookbooks and Women’s Marches
description: “Rage Baking,” which donates some profits to Emily’s List, features recipes and essays from more than 40 contributors.
content: The cover of this timely, political cookbook plays to my personal belief that baking is a release: Punch down that dough with force. The authors, Kathy Gunst, a cookbook writer, and Katherine Alford, a chef and writer, include views and recipes from more than 40 contributors, including Carla Hall, Genevieve Ko, Betty Fussell, Naomi Duguid and Jessica B. Harris. Clever chocolate-vanilla swirl cookies, a lovely Mexican chocolate-almond cake, upside-down cake with fresh pineapple, and chocolate pudding are some highlights, with photos of the sweets alternating with shots of women’s marches. To that point the writer Charlotte Druckman says to take your rage to the streets, not the kitchen. Some of the proceeds are donated to Emily’s List, appropriate enough since the organization’s name is an acronym: Early Money Is Like Yeast — it makes the dough rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Judge Weighs How to Keep Guantánamo’s 9/11 Trial on Track
description: At issue is a defense lawyer’s request to leave the case for health reasons. In court, the prosecutor opposed the move, saying there is no “medical emergency.”

content: A group that opposes affirmative action filed an appeal Tuesday of a federal ruling that Harvard had not intentionally discriminated against Asian-American applicants, ratcheting up a challenge to decades of Supreme Court decisions upholding race-conscious selection in college admissions.

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: What if Trump Wins? Europeans Fear a More Permanent Shift Against Them
description: Many sense the potential for a real parting of ways should the American president get a second term.
content: MUNICH — There was a lot for diplomats and policymakers to consider when they gathered at a recent global security conference in Munich: China rising, Russia meddling, Germany weakening. But the inescapable question — the one that might change the world most immediately for Europe — was whether President Trump would win re-election in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia, Constant Méheut and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: In Europe, Fear Spreads Faster Than the Coronavirus Itself
description: About 40 cases have been confirmed in Europe, but people and places associated with the illness face stigmatization.
content: LONDON — A British man who tested positive for coronavirus was branded a “super spreader,” his every movement detailed by the local media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Bernard Kerik Was Pardoned by President Trump. Who Is He?
description: A high school dropout who became New York’s police commissioner received a full pardon for a 2010 conviction on eight felonies.
content: Bernard B. Kerik, a onetime New York police commissioner and close ally of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, was one of 11 people to receive executive grants of clemency from President Trump on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Coronavirus Epidemic Keeps Growing, but Spread in China Slows
description: The World Health Organization said China’s drastic limits on people’s movement had helped, but experts cautioned against predicting that the worst was over.
content: Read live updates on the coronavirus outbreak here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Does a Driving Test
description: John Guzzetta pulls us right in.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I failed my road test the first time I took it and, in retrospect, it was a good thing that I did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Kim Clijsters Begins Comeback With a Promising Loss
description: Clijsters played her first match on the tour on Monday after eight years away, falling to Garbiñe Muguruza but showing flashes of her former dominant game.
content: After nearly eight years away, Kim Clijsters, now a mother of three, returned to the tennis tour on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 18, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ersilia M. DeFilippis, M.D
title: Hidden Beneath the Hospital Gown
description: In contrast to the authority and protection the doctor’s white coat confers, hospital gowns make patients exposed, vulnerable and stripped of their identity.
content: “Here is your gown,” the nurse had said as she handed over a cotton frock. After hours in the hectic emergency room, we arrived in my mother’s hospital room. My mother quickly assured her that she would not be needing it. She knew she was sick; she did not need the gown to confirm it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy O. Harris
title: Jeremy O. Harris: Brandon Taylor ‘Subjugates Us With the Deft Hand of a Dom’
description: In the debut novel “Real Life,” a biochemistry Ph.D. candidate confronts the harder lessons of how to be a gay black man in a white world.
content: REAL LIFE By Brandon Taylor
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV Tuesday: “Super 8” and “#TEAMPLUTO”
description: A monster movie is available for streaming. And a documentary about the famous dwarf planet is on Discovery.
content: SUPER 8 (2011) Stream on Amazon and Hulu. Rent on Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. Directed by J.J. Abrams and produced by Steven Spielberg, “Super 8” has all the makings of a classic monster movie. It takes place in 1979, in a small Ohio town largely populated by steel workers and their children, including Joe Lamb (Joel Courtney), the story’s protagonist. Joe — who lives with his father, the local sheriff (Kyle Chandler) — is filming a zombie movie with his 11-year-old friends when they witness a train crash, and they investigate. “You know that, in the homestretch, big battles will be fought, lessons will be learned, the elusive monster will be revealed and other loose ends will be tied up,” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times. He adds, “You may wish it did not all happen in such a perfunctory, predictable way.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Government Buildings
description: Should they all look like the Lincoln Memorial?
content: Should every new government building in the nation’s capital be created in the same style as the Lincoln Memorial?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen McDonald
title: A Lesbian Who’s Not a Lesbian Walks Into a Bar, and ...
description: William T. Vollmann’s novel “The Lucky Star,” part of his “transgender trilogy,” is fixated on femininity and the ways it is performed.
content: THE LUCKY STARBy William T. Vollmann
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Laura Vanderkam
title: The Gig Economy Offers Parents Options and Obstacles
description: App-enabled part-time work gives parents flexibility, but long hours don’t guarantee a high paycheck.
content: This piece is part of “The Price of Modern Parenting.” Read more about the sandwich generation, the cost of adoption and out-of-pocket expenses for preterm births.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Encinitas, Calif.: A Beach Town Where Prices Rise With the Tide
description: Twenty-five miles up the coast from San Diego, the small city attracts buyers with its ocean views and solid schools.
content: You’d be hard-pressed to find a more quintessential California surf town than Encinitas, a sun-drenched pocket of coastal North County San Diego where wet suits hang like flags from bungalow porches and taco shops promise “No shirt, no shoes, no problem.” But when Morgan and Trevor Gates moved back to the area in 2018 after spending a year in Boulder, Colo., it wasn’t so much Encinitas’s beachy energy that convinced them to buy a home in the neighborhood of Cardiff-by-the-Sea, with its dramatic bluffs and cluster of oceanfront restaurants. It was its elementary schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Logan
title: From New York to Barcelona, a Poet With His Eye on Politics
description: In his third collection, “Living Weapon,” Rowan Ricardo Phillips invokes superheroes and hard-boiled crime to grapple with gun violence, climate change and more.
content: LIVING WEAPONBy Rowan Ricardo Phillips
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Do You Wear to the End of Days?
description: Or at least the end of the European experiment? At London Fashion Week, Burberry, JW Anderson and Simone Rocha offer some ideas.
content: LONDON — In 1139 Archbishop Malachy of Armagh supposedly had a vision of the future that became known as the “prophesy of popes.” In it, the Irish saint predicted the names of 112 pontiffs who would rule until the end of days. Though it was later shown to be a 16th-century forgery, the second to last pope on the list was Benedict, which has suggested to some in the Roman Catholic world that the final pope could be the current pope, and the apocalypse is nigh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen McDonald
title: A Lesbian Who’s Not a Lesbian Walks Into a Bar, and ...
description: William T. Vollmann’s novel “The Lucky Star,” part of his “transgender trilogy,” is fixated on femininity and the ways it is performed.
content: THE LUCKY STARBy William T. Vollmann
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Tim Gruber
title: The Struggle to Mend America’s Rural Roads
description: As supersize vehicles bear heavier loads, maintenance budgets can’t keep up. Meet the Wisconsin farmers paying the price.
content: Wearing bright safety vests, the county highway workers followed the scalding, red tar kettle as it pumped out liquid rubber bandages, thick as melted butter, to cover the pavement’s worst gashes. From above, it looked like the flip side of skywriting — as if yellow cursors on the ground were carefully spelling out a message for unseen readers in the clouds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: ‘Dracula’ and ‘Frankenstein’? Nothing to Be Scared Of
description: Classic Stage Company is running adaptations of two 19th-century horror classics in repertory. Don’t let that frighten you.
content: If you, like me, have an emotional default set to low-level dread, terror lurks everywhere. Consider the climate emergency, the coronavirus, rising far-right extremism, the disappearance of frogs, crimes over avocados. Last week, I stumbled on a study of hair dye toxicity that sent me into an hourslong Google spiral, and I now know uncomfortable things about p-Phenylenediamine. Which is to say that modern life is scary. So it’s baffling that two new adaptations of horror classics — “Frankenstein” and “Dracula,” running in repertory at Classic Stage Company — are not. In fact, they summon all the terror of a cooling mug of chamomile tea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Selenis Leyva’s Clean Slate
description: The “Orange Is the New Black” actor has a new series and her own space high above it all, where (almost) everything is white — just the way she wanted it.
content: Selenis Leyva barely set foot out of the Bronx until she was accepted at Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Feb. 26, 2020
description: How does the new coronavirus compare to other infectious diseases?
content: This graph, showing the new coronavirus as compared to other infectious diseases, appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com. It uses a log scale, the same type of scale used for measuring earthquakes, where an increase of 1 on the log scale represents a 10-fold increase in the original scale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Clayton Williams, Oilman Whose Gaffes Cost an Election, Dies at 88
description: Leading Ann Richards in 1990, he was undone by a spate of blunders. He was the last Republican to date to lose a race for governor of Texas.
content: Clayton Williams, a West Texas oilman who derailed his 1990 campaign for governor with a spate of crude remarks, including an offensive comment about rape, died on Friday at his home in Midland, Texas. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: All This Dystopia, and for What?
description: When privacy-eroding technology doesn’t deliver on its promises.
content: When you signed up for this newsletter you may have noticed the language indicated it would be a “limited run.” And like all limited runs, ours is coming to an end next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Will Bloomberg Save or Sink the Democrats?
description: The billionaire and former Republican could test the limits of the Democratic dictum to “vote blue no matter who.”
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Has the Best Chance to Beat Trump?
description: Reflecting recent polls, readers don’t agree on a particular candidate.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Najim Rahim and Fatima Faizi
title: Ghani Named Afghan Election Winner. His Opponent Claims Victory, Too.
description: After a five-month dispute over the vote, President Ashraf Ghani won a second term. But a parallel declaration by a main rival threatens a crisis ahead of a U.S.-Taliban peace deal.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Ashraf Ghani on Tuesday was declared the winner of Afghanistan’s presidential vote after five months of delayed results and bitter dispute. But the announcement threatened to tip the country into a full-blown political crisis on the cusp of a U.S. peace deal with the Taliban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Michael Bloomberg Has to Debate Without a Net
description: Candidates are not permitted to haul field organizers or canapés or record-reframing ad campaigns onstage with them. So the former mayor will stand on his own.
content: For months, he has muscled into the Democratic primary with all the glossy ubiquity money can buy — the benevolent billionaire, in his ads’ telling, results-minded and liberal where it counts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Allen Paulos
title: We’re Reading the Coronavirus Numbers Wrong
description: Up-to-the-minute reports and statistics can unintentionally distort the facts.
content: Numbers have a certain mystique: They seem precise, exact, sometimes even beyond doubt. But outside the field of pure mathematics, this reputation rarely is deserved. And when it comes to the coronavirus epidemic, buying into that can be downright dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Video Chats and Ordering In: Coronavirus Quarantine With a Smartphone
description: This is not your grandmother’s quarantine. People are confined and afraid, but their virtual lives have been largely uninterrupted.
content: Yardley Wong, captive on the Japanese cruise ship grappling with the coronavirus, captured in a single image the essence of life under quarantine. From inside her tiny cabin, Ms. Wong took a picture of the closed doorway. She posted it to Twitter last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oyinkan Braithwaite
title: Murder and White Privilege on a Family Holiday in the Caribbean
description: In Alexis Schaitkin’s debut, a woman tries to solve the mystery of her sister’s death on the island of “Saint X.”
content: In 1995, on a nameless Caribbean island, an American family is on holiday. The Thomases are no better or worse than any of the other upper-middle-class white tourists who are also vacationing in sultry Indigo Bay, with its “everywhere weeping pink blooms and … brazen teal water.” But the night before they are supposed to go home, the older of the couple’s two daughters, 18-year-old Alison, is nowhere to be found. Within a couple of days, her body is found dead in a nearby cay.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy, From Beautiful Crime to Essays on Identity
description: A selection of recent books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: A BEAUTIFUL CRIME, by Christopher Bollen. (Harper/HarperCollins, $28.99.) In this elegant crime thriller, a couple of New Yorkers contrive to sell counterfeit antiques to an unsuspecting American expat in Venice, but all does not go according to plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Pete Buttigieg Before the Nevada Caucuses
description: The former mayor of South Bend, Ind., has cherry-picked his record on minority poverty and arrests, overstated his consistency on health policy and used a questionable rationale to attack a rival.
content: Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., has had strong showings in the first two Democratic presidential nominating contests. As he seeks to build support ahead of Nevada’s vote on Saturday, Mr. Buttigieg has sought to explain his record with black residents of South Bend, distinguish himself from his competitors on health care, and parry attacks on the issue of campaign finance. Here’s a fact check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Life at Caleta 111 Revolves Around Limes and Tiger’s Milk
description: A new Peruvian restaurant in Richmond Hill, Queens, specializes in ceviche and its citrus-based marinade.
content: The Queens neighborhood of Richmond Hill is far from Lima both geographically and atmospherically. This has not stopped Peruvian restaurants from sprouting up there. They line Jamaica Avenue under the shuddering elevated tracks of the J train, which by the time it gets here is nearly at the end of the line. Most are modest in spirit and unprepossessing in appearance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Dortmund’s Erling Haaland Adds to His Totals, and to His Legend
description: Borussia Dortmund’s teenage striker scored twice in a win over Paris St.-Germain in the Champions League, once again making a tough job look simple.
content: DORTMUND, Germany — Borussia Dortmund’s players hung back a little, idling halfway between the center circle and the goal. With Paris St.-Germain jerseys slung over their shoulders, the spoils of battle, they clapped each other on the back, they exchanged high fives, they ruffled each others’ hair. Most of all, though, they waited for him to have his moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: In ‘Coal Country,’ Memories From a Mining Tragedy Live On
description: A new documentary play at the Public Theater weaves together interviews from people whose lives were forever changed by the 2010 mining disaster in West Virginia.
content: Six years after the explosion that killed 29 coal miners in West Virginia, family members and co-workers of the dead weren’t answering phone calls from the New York playwright.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor, Heather Murphy and Mariel Padilla
title: A Complete List of Trump’s Pardons and Commutations
description: The president granted full pardons to seven people and commutations to four others on Tuesday. Here’s who they are.
content: President Trump pardoned seven people on Tuesday, including the “junk bond king” Michael R. Milken and Bernard B. Kerik, a former New York City police commissioner. He also commuted the sentences of Rod R. Blagojevich, a former governor of Illinois, and three others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Shop Has Gone to the Dogs
description: At Not Just Chocolate in Park Slope, Brooklyn, the specialty is the choclified pooch.
content: Sergei Potekhin will not disclose how he and his wife, Lena, create their chocolate menagerie, mainly many breeds of dogs. Mr. Potekhin calls it a “proprietary technique,” though it looks like the figures in milk, dark and white chocolates are sculpted; some might also be molded. The couple started in Russia, where Ms. Potekhin worked for the chocolate giant Mars; her husband was in marketing. They started their chocolate work in Russia, moved to Brooklyn in 2018 and opened their shop last fall. In addition to the animals, they make other kinds of chocolates and chocolate pastries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: You Can Check Out Any Time You Like
description: Hotels are embracing more flexible check-in and checkout times — a move that changes the guest experience, particularly for business and red-eye travelers.
content: When Sydni Brecher landed in Paris early one morning around Christmas last year, she didn’t kill precious euros in a cafe or seek refuge at an airport lounge waiting for her accommodations to be ready.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Report Reveals Insider Dealing at Russia’s Antidoping Agency
description: A forensic audit of Russia’s antidoping agency has suggested former officials funneled money to companies they controlled.
content: A forensic audit of Russia’s scandal-plagued antidoping agency appears to have unearthed a new problem: hundreds of thousands of dollars, and perhaps more, paid to companies linked to former senior executives at the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Steven Lee Myers
title: U.S. Designates China’s Official Media as Operatives of the Communist State
description: The move is the latest in the Trump administration’s efforts to counter Beijing’s influence and intelligence operations in the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — For years they have operated as news organizations in the United States, deploying scores of journalists to cover the major events of the day and to report back to their readers and viewers at home, even if the most important of those was the leadership of the Communist Party of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Daytona 500: How Ryan Newman’s Last Lap Ended in Flames
description: Newman was in position to win the Daytona 500 on the race’s final turn Monday. Then everything went wrong, leaving him hospitalized and his colleagues trying to sort out a chaotic finish.
content: There are 200 scheduled laps in the Daytona 500, but it was the last one of this year’s race on Monday that will be most remembered. In a few chaotic moments, Ryan Newman’s car edged into the lead on the final turn, crashed, flipped onto its roof and then was hit broadside by another car. In the fiery aftermath of the accident, Denny Hamlin won the race, the crowd fell silent and Newman skidded down the track in a shower of sparks and flames.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: At Vail Dance Festival, a Season of Premieres and Ballet Stars
description: Calvin Royal III, from American Ballet Theater, will be the artist in residence. He’ll perform a premiere by Tiler Peck of New York City Ballet.
content: Calvin Royal III, the American Ballet Theater soloist who has had star turns in classics like Balanchine’s “Apollo,” will be the artist in residence at this year’s Vail Dance Festival, which was announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times
